column1: The vocal cords are part of your voice box (larynx) located in the throat.
A rare but serious cause of hoarseness that does not go away in a few weeks is cancer of the voice box.

Hoarseness may be caused by: - Acid reflux (gastroesophageal reflux) - Allergies - Breathing in irritating substances - Cancer of the throat or larynx - Chronic coughing - Colds or upper respiratory infections - Heavy smoking or drinking, especially together - Overuse or abuse of the voice (as in shouting or singing), which may cause swelling or growths on the vocal cords Less common causes include: - Injury or irritation from a breathing tube or bronchoscopy - Damage to the nerves and muscles around the voice box (from trauma or surgery) - Foreign object in the esophagus or trachea - Swallowing a harsh chemical liquid - Changes in the larynx during puberty - Thyroid or lung cancer - Underactive thyroid gland
Rest and time may improve hoarseness.
- Take medicines to reduce stomach acid if hoarseness is due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
Call your health care provider if: - You have trouble breathing or swallowing.
- Hoarseness occurs with drooling, especially in a small child.
- Hoarseness occurs in a child less than 3 months old.
- Hoarseness has lasted for more than 1 week in a child, or 2 to 3 weeks in an adult.
- Do you have other symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, weight loss, or fatigue?
